label: AB2_tP24_137_g_cdf-001
title: Orange (II) HgI$_{2}$ Structure
comments: HgI$_{2}$ can be found in a variety of forms (Gumi\'{n}ski, 1997): \begin{itemize} \item The ground state, \href{current_web_home_dir/AB2_tP6_137_a_d-001}{coccinite}, also known as red or $\alpha$-HgI$_{2}$ and given the {\em Strukturbericht} designation $C13$.  It is stable up to 135$^\circ$C. \item At higher temperatures this transforms into yellow or $\beta$-HgI$_{2}$ in the \href{current_web_home_dir/A2B_oC12_36_2a_a-001}{HgBr$_{2}$ ($C24$) structure}.  This is stable up to the melting point at 258$^\circ$C. \item (Schwarzenbach, 1969) studied the metastable \href{current_web_home_dir/AB2_tI48_141_h_2eg-001}{orange HgI$_{2}$} body-centered tetragonal ($I4_{1}/amd$ \#141) phase. This structure was refined by (Hostettler, 2002). \item (Hostettler, 2002) also found a \href{current_web_home_dir/AB2_tP24_137_g_cdf-001}{second orange HgI$_{2}$ phase} (this structure) in a simple tetragonal ($P4_{2}/nmc$ \#137) cell. \item The last two structures differ by stacking order. (Hostettler, 2002) used them to produce an \href{current_web_home_dir/AB2_tP12_115_j_egi-001}{averaged   orange HgI$_{2}$ structure}, space group $P\overline{4}m2$ \#115. \end{itemize}
